data.text: Bicycle Touring at an Older Age

Any of you start Bicycle touring at a older age? I am just starting and only doing three or four day trips at a time. I am 46 years old. I plan on doing much longer touring when I retire. I will be 55 at that time.
right with you...saving funds to begin soon
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: Did a few short tours with kids when I was in my 30s, but took up proper touring, 3 months at a time when I was made redundant at 55. Now 62 and planning longer trips still.
data.author: Robin Symonds

data.text: 61
data.author: Mick Hine

data.text: My Dad 71 started last year with the Gap and C&O 6 DAYS.
data.author: Shawn Zumbrum

data.text: Did my my first overnight and 3 day. Age 49. Never to late to start!
data.author: Chris Webb

data.text: I've only done one overnight and that was just this year. I'm 49. No options for a while to do multi night rides but I'll take what I can get.
data.author: Jason Clark

data.text: I am 58 and during the summer I made 2 short trips (3 nites total) - mainly to test my gear. It worked so end september I am heading for a 3 month trip to USA üòé
data.author: Kim Becke

data.text: I came back to cycling at 58 have gradually built up my fitness and touring days. Next year I am planning a 1000km 2 week tour. After that ‚Ä¶ who knows üòÇüòÇ
data.author: Guy Burton

data.text: Started riding and credt card touring at 65 after nearly 50 years of no biking.
data.author: Dell Edwards

data.text: Yikes when did 46 become an older age üòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇüò≠üò≠
data.author: Theresa Lu

data.text: First overnighter at 48. Looking forward to more
data.author: Rob Husband

data.text: More important than age is your basic state of health. I did my first long tour (Paris-Barcelona) when I was 21 and then nothing really for many, many years, though I kept relatively healthy. Then I started my nomadic lifestyle again, cycling and working at the same time, at age 50, not so much at first, but more intensively from age 52 on. Now I'm 63. I think no matter what shape you're in, if you start slowly and build up, within a couple of years you can get back into shape, and regardless, you should never try to overdo it. I plan to continue cycling if I can until I'm 80 or more, LOL, if I make it to that age.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: For example, in the last 11 or 12 years, I've done some 50.000 km by bike through 40 countries. Sometimes I stay in one place for 3 weeks or even 3 months; otherwise, I'm constantly on the move, wild/stealth camping, in hostels, sometimes renting a place.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Short tour when I was 18 and started again 39 years later at 57. It's not a race, you can tour at any age.
data.author: Graham Ogle

data.text: I started at 55 üòé Since, every year doing longer and harder trips
data.author: Elie BD

data.text: I'm 60 and just getting back into it. Bikes have been a great part of my life no matter where in the world I found myself.
data.author: Charles Sleep

data.text: Did my first multiday a month ago I'm 48
data.author: Mark Holland

data.text: I did my first touring ride from Land‚Äôs End to John O‚ÄôGroats in May. I qualify as being older. I‚Äôm 68 üòÄ

data.text: how long did it take you? Did you camp or go for luxury option?üòÇ

data.text: hi, the trip took 14 days averaging 70 -75 miles a day. I stayed in B&Bs and hostels. A good sleep each night was part of the strategy üòÄ

data.text: I hope to do that trip one day, likely when I retire.

data.text: fix a date then plan ahead. Just don‚Äôt leave it as long as I did üòÄ

data.text: I agree with Peter. Don‚Äôt wait too long as that day may never come.

data.text: Yes I know. Can‚Äôt do it yet as I live in Singapore. This is my weekly ride : RTI (Round The Island) approx 110kms. I look at these touring sites for inspiration for the futureüëçüèª.

data.text: I slept well camping.

data.text: you did well the. I‚Äôm not sure I could have carried camping kit and done the daily mileage needed for a 14 day trip.

data.text: nice one üëç

data.text: I later finished on my own from Blaenau Ffestiniog to Bangor and Llandudno Junction then train home.

data.text: lovely part of the world. üëç
data.author: John Cooper

data.text: The Radnor Ring was another that we did. It goes through Llandrindod Wells where there is a cycle museum. The 3 of us went round the museum then Maggie sat down . Her husband Jim and I went round a second time then I sat down with Maggie while Jim went round a 3rd time. We started and finished at Llanbister Road station as It is a circular route.
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: üëç there are thousands of challenges and cycle routes out there, i hope to start ticking some off next spring, baby willing. ü§£. Enjoy your cycling and stay safe.
data.author: John Cooper

data.text: that should read body willing, ü§£
data.author: John Cooper

data.text: I'm 60 and did my first long tour abroad this year, 12 nights cycling around Switzerland with a colleague who's 62. Last year we did the coast to coast in North of England over 3 nights

data.text: same here. 59
data.author: David Quast

data.text: I started my tour at 47, no warm ups or practice rides‚Ä¶ hadn‚Äôt been on a bike in a decade or more. 2300 miles into my ride now (I‚Äôm still 47)
data.author: Nesta Skychild

data.text: My first long trip will be in april...then I will be 70 üòÄ will do the rhine approx 2000 km starting from DK. Age is just a figure...true age is what you feel inside.
data.author: Birte Ph

data.text: I was riding the Pan American trail from Anchorage to Cabo on my 55th birthday. You are only as old as you feel.
data.author: Chris Montano

data.text: I am a newbie and 43. I haven't done anything longer than a couple nights but next year I plan on doing some very long rides.

data.text: I'm passed 50, just started learning to cycle for health reasons.
data.author: Sarah Cheng

data.text: I started at 60 had not being on bicycle since I was 15 . Started using a bicycle to compute to shops and back to get fit . Enjoyed more than I expected , and got fitter and fitter . Trips got longer and longer . Then started to do overnighter and trips away . Much better than hiking , can travel much further and see so much more . Hooked
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: Muscle memory - when your cells reproduce every seven years they produce more mitochondria than before if you're training, less if you are not
data.author: Sean Patrick Donovan

data.text: Started actively at 47, getting ready to do regular week trips, now 48

data.text: I‚Äôm 51 and started this year; 500 miles in to my first tour of more than 2 days.

data.text: I did Cal coast @ 40 , Sw Ireland to NE Scotland At 50.. Now I need to stay in one place to have my medication to preserve my eyesight mailed from VA Pharmacy. (Or Glaucoma will painfully blind me) Im now pootling locally, my touring bags get groceries in them..

data.text: I started touring much later than that and really enjoy it.
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: I'm 46 and on my first tour right now. I bought my bike two weeks before I left and I am touring Europe for a year, 23 countries planned.

data.text: are They fairly quiet?

data.text: Not me started at age 26 in 1982. 8 months a year and 40 years later I'm 66 now and in a month I'll start my 41st year touring. It's a great, cheap way to travel and see the world. I've been 300,000 miles.

data.text: I‚Äôm starting at 55. You‚Äôre only as old as you feel (or your knees tell you üòÇ)

data.author: James C Openshaw

data.text: please bear with me if readers have heard this story before,,,i work in the schools, worked one summer at yellowstone natl park..once or twice a week we would get what we referred to as hiker/bikers and they were always interesting,,,many from across the u s or other countries. I worked in the campground and it was a treat for me to chat with all of them i could..maybe the most interesting guy was a teacher from san antonio, the area where i grew up..he was one year from retirement and told his boys thru the years he would ride his kmart bike to ynp,,,as they became teens they would laugh and laugh,,,"sure you will dad"....he loaded his bike and they had no clue,,,he called them from an hour from home to let them know he was fine and riding,,,he had no conditioning, didnt consult with his doctor,,an overhanging gut like mine, plenty of gray hair and a bike way overpacked,,,he confessed he walked the bike as much as he rode it,,,,,i asked him if he was gonna be riding back,,he said "hell no!, this bike cost be about 35.00 sometime in the late 70s at kmart..im throwing that bike in your dumpster right THERE, takin a bus to bozeman and flyin back so SA but not before taking a bunch of photos to prove to my sons that i was here!"....around 1200 miles
data.author: Joe Dyer

data.text: üëçüëçüëç

data.text: First bike trips summer after college. Retired in 2019 and did a 10-day bike trip last year at 58. Biked a lot in between college and 2020. Then I got a touring bike. Now have at least 8-10 years of bike trips planned including a cross country trip (US). I am not breaking any speed records and I am comfortable walking up big hills. Loving every minute of my bike trips.

data.text: I am 67 and I just completed a 1100 mile bike tour of New York State over 18 dats. Started riding at 57 and have logged 20,000 miles over the last 10 years. You are still a youngster! Start slow and easy and let the experience take hold over time. Good luck, and enjoy...

data.text: I remember thinking 28 was old when I was 22!

data.text: lol. Funny! I've never thought about people as old, even if they are in their 90's, unless they are immobile. Then I think they are old.

data.text: Yes! We started cycling at 50. Now we are 56, our first long tour is in 6 months!
data.author: Susie AndDarren Hamm

data.text: I'm 63 and did my first tour this summer. Only 50 km a day.
data.author: Lidwien Fokkinga

data.text: I started at 60. Female nana on a e bike. Rode the north island and doing the south in march
data.author: Sharon Rae

data.text: After not having cycled past age 16, I started again at age 57. Since then (now age 85) I‚Äôve logged over 190,000 kilometres across 30 countries. My last long ride at age 79 was from Ottawa Canada to Chicago then Route 66 to Santa Monika with side trips to Grand Canyon, Phoenix & San Diego for a total of over 7000 kilometres. Unfortunately, Covid put a crimp on my adventures, however did manage an 1,100 + kilometre ride across the Canadian Rockies at age 83. Moral of the story, GO FOR IT! You‚Äôre never too old to start.
data.author: Andre Marier

data.text: Wow! Amazing! Great job! That‚Äôs a lot of miles!
data.author: Nicola McDuffie

data.text:
Started bike touring in March 2021 at age 65 with Southern Tier. Kept a journal at www.trailjournals.com/southerntier. You will be young when you start. Starting October 10 - Richmond VA to Key West, FL
Southern Tier's 2021 Other Trails Journal : Part of Trail Journals' Backpacking and Hiking Journals
trailjournals.com
data.author: Jim Beeson

data.text: Im 54 and have most of the kit to go across Europƒô, i just need to find the time, I will do 60miles in a day regularly (ebike though, 45miles was my max on pedal only without all the luggage) but will start from home and arrive at home, unfortunately my job is sourcing semi conductors, so at the moment to take the time off is impossible, but if things get really bad and the end product (automotive) market gives up and cuts back, I plan to ask for a sabbatical,. As long as you a reasonably healthy and not planning to treat it as a race, you will be fine, just start with more hotel stops than camp stops and build up from there
data.author: Simon Jap McClelland

data.text: At 59, I did 240 miles in July and am planning 4500km next summer when I will be 60. My first 2 tours.
data.author: Andy Girvan

data.text: I ‚Äúrestarted‚Äù at age 48; now 58 and still can do 70 miles on a loaded bike

data.text: A friend used to run, but only really took up cycling after he retired. Within a few years he represented GB in the Triathlon (in his age group) in the world championships.
data.author: Shirley Acreman

data.text: I‚Äôm 54 and did my first bike packing trip in June, in November i‚Äôm jumping in at the deep end and off to do the Carretera Austral in Chile southern half.

data.text: I did my first tour in 1986 when I was 27, then didn't tour again until 2021 when I did a four day, 170 mile trip. ! I am planning more for this year.

data.text: Recently started weekend ‚Äòcredit card‚Äô tours at 65.

data.text: We are 64 and going to do our first tour on the Katy trail in Oct. looking forward So she doesn‚Äôt matter. You will be young when you retire!!!! Lucky you!!!!

data.author: Al Galletly

data.text: My husband and I started touring in our 60s! We are retired and, thus, have much flexibility in our schedule. It‚Äôs fabulous! üö¥üö¥

data.text: 46 is not old wow

data.text: 70 is the new 50!
data.author: Mary Ann Latzgo Padglick

data.text: Kids!
data.author: Mary Ann Latzgo Padglick

data.text: Just do it. I dropped out of corporate America when I was 55, did 118 miles of "training" and me, my Surly Long Haul Trucker and BOB trailer took off and rode the TransAmerica Trail across the US, 4,100 miles. Age is mostly a state of mind.
data.author: David Jones

data.text: love it. That‚Äôs what I want to do. I‚Äôll be 55 in February and can‚Äôt take another minute of corporate BS
data.author: Darice Brown Taxter

data.text: I am 62 and just started. I hotel it.
data.author: Patricia Seifert

data.text: Still riding and touring at 64, some of our club members are still doing tours at 70+ Your never to old
data.author: Alan Norris

data.text: I'm 46 and started active biking from April of this year.. just completed 6000 Kms.. started by doing about 15 Kms per day @ about 15kmph.. did my first 50 Kms on World Bicycle Day.. currently doing 75 Kms per day @ about 23.5kmph..
data.author: Dutta Rajdeep

data.text: Yes! You can do it. We started to seriously ride when we were 57. Rode a 100 miles when I was 58. We have bike packed the GAP and C&O, Katy Trail and many other trails multiple times. We have done 60, 70 and 80+ miles a days bike packing. Rain or shine any day spent on a bike is a good day!
data.author: Becky Potts

data.text: I‚Äôm 66 and still at it.

data.text: Enjoy your camping - not too hot now. I camped with my bike a fortnight ago.

data.text: I did 1250 kms in twelve days, a month ago, and finished on the eve of my 63rd birthday. It was my first long distance, multi day tour and for the best part, I did it solo!

data.text: Whipper-snapper üòÇ

data.text: Age doesn't matter... I started at 20 with a trans Canadian ride from west to east... along the way I met guys in their 60s going strong. üòéüåà

data.text: Why not. You can do a lot in your 60s.

data.text: Well done with no car all those years. I don't miss mine - no parking problems. I have 2 Bromptons so that I always have one to ride if the other needs attention. 2 friends and I cycled and camped on many Sustrans routes in our 70s but they have health problems now so I go on my own. Sometimes I go on a coach trip taking the bike with me to cycle in a different area. Enjoy!

data.text: I'm going to next summer, I'll be 61.

data.author: Joseph Delagarza

data.text: My mom is 69. She did RAGBRAI in July. 461 miles across Iowa Sunday-Saturday, she ended up riding about every other day, for a total of 200 miles, sagging with my 11-year-old daughter when necessary. Camped every night! Prior to 2022, the longest bike ride she'd ever been on was about 15-20 miles. She started training on an indoor bike trainer (the bike she planned to use, set up in a trainer) in January 2022, and she was in reasonable physical shape to start with - she walks 2-4 miles every day with my parents' dog. She used Trainer Road to come up with her training plans, and watched Doctor Who as her "treat" for training sessions.
data.author: Elizabeth Wiczer

data.text: I did my first long trip - 5 weeks in France - at 48. I‚Äôve since done trips in central and Eastern Europe (bottom part of EV6), UK and Canada as well as shorter trips closer to home in Australia. On my next trip I will be 60 and riding EV6 from the Atlantic coast of France to Budapest.
data.author: Margie Joyce

data.text: I started bicycle touring at 75 üòé, It's never too late ü§©
data.author: Peter Davis

data.text: I'm 57 , and just getting back into it.
data.author: Kevin Harlow

data.text: Better late than never. Most imp is to reach your destination & enjoy the view. It doesnt matter how slow or fast. Were not d tour de france.
data.author: Ahmad Rostam

data.text: I'm shooting for San Diego to Argentina at 66....don't think about the numbers....it's how you feel...
data.author: Silvio Suarez

data.text: First tour age 61
data.author: Becky Robertson

data.text: Yes! At age 48 and after 15 years of being addicted to smoking cigarettes, I used biking as recovery method. I am 51 today and can bike about 50 miles per day for a weekend tour!
data.author: Mark Millstone

data.text: I started at 47
data.author: Jesse Justice

data.text: My husband and I started at 54 and at 63 still going. We ride every other day 40-60 miles. üö≤üö≤
data.author: Robin Mixter-Pauley

data.text: Yes, well‚Ä¶ not as old as I am now. I turned 50 climbing Lolo Pass in Montana. Still doing shorter trips, but may have another epic or two in me. Just had 69th birthday.
data.author: Jeffrey Kingdon

data.text: Started @ 44
data.author: Nick Greenwood

data.text: I'm 52 and this was supposed to be my first summer doing a tour. However due to too many changes it had to be put off. üòì. Hopefully next spring!
data.author: Darryl Pierce

data.text: did my first 4 day trip at 47 then at 50 rode East Coast Tassie 702km to be exact... overdue for another adventure!!!! Do it!
data.author: Arabella Watson

data.text: 63 and I just got home from a tour of the Washington coast.
data.author: Lorena Corzatt

data.text: At 47 I did my first tour just to finally do one. Never finished but had a great time
data.author: Robert Provenzano

data.text: The later, the better, said the Procrastinator
data.author: Adrian Constantin Craciun

data.text: I am 62 and want to start, but haven‚Äôt done so yet.
data.author: Steve Moe

data.text: Not sure 46 is old, there is an 84 year old solo in barren Australia... ü§îI believe It's the fitness of your mind more than your body to get you through a tour or any endurance event. Not a race just your own time.
data.author: Mardelle N David Hudson

data.text: 46 ain‚Äôt old!
data.author: Emma Adams

data.text: I‚Äôm almost half through a solo cross country tour at 67. Pretty much started last year with a two 3 day and one 3 week tour. Had only done a 2 and 3 day a couple years before that. Age is almost irrelevant. Attitude is what counts. Ps. Did 73 miles today on fully loaded touring bike and not a big deal. Just need to keep the pedals moving‚Ä¶
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: Any tips for those of us who are JUST starting out? (49 years old:)
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: I'm 40, wish to do solo ride over the city.
data.author: Nasim Taimuri

data.text: 63 did my first multi day ride in August
data.author: Brian Saul

data.text: I started at 51...try to ride as many days as you can in a row but dont worry about speed or distance. Stop when you feel pain and just get used to the saddle first :)
data.author: Ernesto Verger

data.text: I did lands end to John o groats over three weeks at the age of 52?
data.author: Sarah Smith

data.text: Met the Frenchman down in Argrntina or Chile ( not sure where on the road ) but he was in his 70s cyclist, cycling naked to some French nudist Cruse Ship living from Ushuaia , so age my friend makes you only do what you always wanted. Kudos and safe travels
data.author: Arek Thun Czuchraj

data.text: I started At 66 years old, still working up to the "Big Ride" ...
data.author: David Jensen
David Jensen

data.text: For my 60th I did the ‚ÄòJogle‚Äô on my mountain bike and all my camping gear. Wild camping most of the way
data.author: David Bailey

data.text: I was 68 when I did my first tour, that was 1200 miles from Washington DC to Walton IA. Just did my second one with my wife from Hope Mills NC to Rapid City, SD, at 69. Never to late to start.
data.author: Randy Johnson

data.text: I've only done 'credit card' touring (ie staying at B&Bs etc) but I started at the age of 46!
data.author: Stephen Kingdom

data.text: Oh yes, I'm hoping to tour when we're retired! I'm now 54 years, so counting the years....
data.author: Inge Van T Klooster-Roos

data.text: 46 with 9 years to prepare .... enjoy the riding you will have no troubles!
data.author: John Anderson

data.text: Just started at 63
data.author: Nikki Radcliffe

data.text: I'm only starting just now myself...at the age of 67. First up, the 333 mile (the "lite" version) of the HuRaCan 300.
data.author: Timothy Ettridge

data.text: There‚Äôs no time like present - don‚Äôt wait until you‚Äôre 55.
data.author: Janet O'Toole

data.text: 'Older' my behind. With a modern 99 year expectancy, at 46 you're not even past the 2/3 mark yet, & still won't be when you take early retirement at 55. Stop pity-framing yourself as 'older', you middle aged hypochondriac. You're in your best years now. :)
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: Not many people expect 99 years or not 99 active years.
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: I started this summer. I'll be 72 in 2 weeks
data.author: Gary Arnold

data.text: I worry about the same, although I am a lot older than you. Would love to do long tours S.A., Asia, Africa, etc., but extended time off won‚Äôt happen for a few more yrs (at best) when I‚Äôm 63ish, god willing‚Ä¶ I am encouraged by the great fitness of riders older than me and just try to keep up!
data.author: Laurel Loukx

data.text: I just retired at 62. I'm now 1,200 km into a tour from Amsterdam to Vienna. I was quite overweight when I started, but I'm really enjoying the whole thing. Before this I would just do day tours of between 30km and 80km. Go for it!
data.author: John Keith

data.text: I started at age 71 and love it.
data.author: Kathleen Gosenheimer

data.text: I‚Äôm in my 50s and experiencing it. Although I did start before covid hit‚Ä¶ Never too old
data.author: Pauline Hammy

data.text: 60
data.author: Nick Windsor

data.text: Born in 1922 and still riding weekend rides overnight in camps
data.author: Frank Parker

data.text: Uhhh, 46 is NOT older, neither is 55. Go forth, spread your wings.
data.author: Dennis Dugger

data.text: I‚Äôm just starting and have no idea what I‚Äôm doing. Building a bike now and bought my chair haha. I‚Äôm going to be 55
data.author: Darice Brown Taxter

data.text: At 55 you should be ready to go:))
data.author: Bryn Graham

data.text: That's the prime of life I just road with people in their 70s for 460 MI last summer they rode from Oregon to Washington DC's

data.text: Yes, I started again at 74 after a 50 yr hiatus.
data.author: Ellis Hallmark

data.text: I started road cycling seriously in my late forties. Planning to start touring now at 67.
data.author: David Saenz

data.text: 46 isn‚Äôt older! üòÇ. You‚Äôre a spring chicken. I highly recommend France and the many canal / river cycling as the cycle ways are fab. PM me if you would like any info. üíñüö¥üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüíñ
data.author: Indigo Kelly-Forest

data.text: I did my first solo long trip at 50. Planning another bigger one next year when I‚Äôll be 54. Didn‚Äôt feel old. And my legs looked great at the end üòâ
data.author: Emma Adams

data.text: Good for you that you have STARTED NOW! You are wise and will be able to use your wisdom as you learn and ride! RIDE ON!!!!! ;-)
data.author: Irisha Brown

data.text: I'm 41 and about to do my first back packing trip. Just a solo one nighter but looking forward to it!
data.author: Doug Binnie

data.text: 62 when I had my first trip!
data.author: Vicki Ford

data.text: I started touring at 54 and just completed an 800 k ride. Keep moving and keep learning new things. üëè
data.author: Debbie Lynn Bowman

data.text: My first bike touring trip of more than a week was cross-country at age 61. It was magical. Even if you don't feel in peak shape, your body will build up. So many lessons learned. I did another lengthy one at 64 and plan to do others.
data.author: Peter Diotte

data.text: I started bike touring around age 60. I‚Äôm now 69 and still going strong.
data.author: Maria Scatena Vangilder

data.text: Hallo, I'm 54 and a week into a tour across Germany via the Elberadweg and starting the EV2 tomorrow all the way to the coast of Belgium and then south to paris. Mostly wildcamping with the occasional campground for a rest. It's a beautiful trip and time. I would recommend it and not waiting for retirement.
data.author: James Patock

data.text: Well I am 61 looking to do that and bikepack
data.author: Perry Zeiger

data.text: - my advice is don‚Äôt wait to start doing weeklong trips ‚Äòtil later‚Ä¶ start now‚Ä¶ I wasn‚Äôt old (18) when I did my first 3 day solo trip, right after high school. The next year I did a 360 mile, 4 day solo trip across PA on the diagonal, including a 160 mile finale. Those 2 trips and lots of yearly riding boosted me to start week long bike trips as my kiddos got older, the whole family riding the GAP/C&O in 2002. Since about 2007 I‚Äôve done typically 2-3 weeklong trips every year‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt wait, the years start going fast like a downhill plunge‚Ä¶ üòâ

data.text: I am 50 and a woman and I also want to start. Let's do this!üí™

data.text: Yes you do it! 50 is young.

data.text: I retired at 64 and since then I have done multi country touring. Usually about 1500 kms. I am 73 this year and i am planning next years trip.

data.text: I was 61 when I began. I am now 65.

data.text: I started riding bike when I was 41 and am now 71. Had a running injury and a botched surgery on my ankle.

data.text: Well done!

data.text: there is a term out there called the Eddington number. It's the number of your longest rides you have done. My number is 102 meaning I have ridden 102 rides over 100 miles.

data.text: Brilliant!
